timeline.body:
hash code should not use non-final members; if values change the hashcode changes. 

This causes trouble, e.g. when an object is added to a hashmap and then the hashcode changes afterwards

dito for other hashcode methods

timeline.bodyHTML:
Maybe rewrite whole test

Pseudocode

try (softly = new SoftAssertions()) {
  for (var algo : AlgoEnum.values()) {
   backPressure.setAlgorithm(algo.name.toLowerCase());

   softly.AssertThat(backPressure.getAlgorithm()).isEqualTo(algo);
  }
}

I know some people don't like this style. But it's less maintenance when you add new algos in the future.
timeline.author: pihme

replies.bodyText: Not sure about this. What we want to test is that the strings are mapped to to the correct enum. If we use the enums to generate the string, isn't it defeating the purpose?
replies.author: deepthidevaki

timeline.body:
Optional: I know you only changed the class, bit there is one thing bothering me about the code that is already here. Feel free to ignore or implement this comment.

the algorithm is stored as a String internally. The  string is not checked in the setter. It will throw exceptions in the getter if the wrong string is passed in. In my mind there should be at least be a check whether the string can be parsed to an enum. And once we do that, we might as well use the enum as internal representation

timeline.body:
that does not work. Suppress warnings is a general annotation. To tell it to ignore sonar qube warnings, you would need
`@SuppressWarnings("squid:common-java:DuplicatedBlocks")` where _squid_ stands for SonarQube Unique ID, I guess.

Not sure whether you need to have _common-java_ in or not. When I used it, I didn't need it. I guess SonarQube knows it is looking at Java already. 

Alternatively, I also found:
> For instance, you can add the following property to your scanner configuration:
> sonar.cpd.exclusions=path/to/your/package/*.java
on this page: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52865737/how-do-i-ignore-duplicated-code-report-in-sonar

I guess this could be set somewehere in the pom files, but I haven't done it yet.
timeline.bodyText:
that does not work. Suppress warnings is a general annotation. To tell it to ignore sonar qube warnings, you would need
@SuppressWarnings("squid:common-java:DuplicatedBlocks") where squid stands for SonarQube Unique ID, I guess.
Not sure whether you need to have common-java in or not. When I used it, I didn't need it. I guess SonarQube knows it is looking at Java already.
Alternatively, I also found:

For instance, you can add the following property to your scanner configuration:
sonar.cpd.exclusions=path/to/your/package/*.java
on this page: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52865737/how-do-i-ignore-duplicated-code-report-in-sonar

I guess this could be set somewehere in the pom files, but I haven't done it yet.
timeline.bodyHTML:
that does not work. Suppress warnings is a general annotation. To tell it to ignore sonar qube warnings, you would need
@SuppressWarnings("squid:common-java:DuplicatedBlocks") where squid stands for SonarQube Unique ID, I guess.

Not sure whether you need to have common-java in or not. When I used it, I didn't need it. I guess SonarQube knows it is looking at Java already.

Alternatively, I also found:

For instance, you can add the following property to your scanner configuration:
sonar.cpd.exclusions=path/to/your/package/*.java
on this page: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52865737/how-do-i-ignore-duplicated-code-report-in-sonar

I guess this could be set somewehere in the pom files, but I haven't done it yet.
